utterances: Lenny, thanks very much for the call.

It's been great being with you.

I don't.

It's not too late.
That's your new book.
It's not too late.
Well, actually, it's not too late for you to start.
Tuesdays with Dorie is moving on.
Well, Dorie Greenspan, thanks very much for your time, and go have a wonderful dinner in Paris tonight.
Thanks so much, Neal.
Dorie Greenspan, by the way, the inspiration for the group of baking enthusiasts on the Internet.
You can bake with Dorie as well.
Her recipe for Chocolate Armagnac Cake, the cake that got her fired, is on her website.
Go to npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION, from NPR News.
Scores of Syrian refugees are making a dangerous journey across the Mediterranean to escape the conflict in their country.
Many are dying along the way.
German activists are trying to shock their government into action, so they've taken an extreme measure.
They exhumed the bodies of two refugees who perished at sea and were buried in unmarked graves in Italy, and then they took those bodies to Berlin.
NPR's Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson reports.
(Speaking Arabic).
Imam Abdullah Hajjir recites Muslim prayers for the dead.
His two assistants shovel dirt onto a white coffin in this Lutheran cemetery.
(Speaking Arabic).
(Speaking German).
These people are sinking in the Mediterranean,"" he explains, ""but we are sinking in injustice, racism and discrimination.
We are responsible."" The imam, who has preached in Berlin for three decades, pleaded with German politicians to do more, to do better.

(SOUNDBITE OF NEWS CONFERENCE)
(Speaking German).
Donna Brazile let's start with an issue that's going to become before the Congress soon which is the U.S.
and the Bush Administration granting India help with nuclear weapons and nuclear power.
In fact, coming after India violated the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty.
Why is the Bush Administration granting such access to India when it clearly is turning its back on others who seek nuclear weapons?
Juan, I think the decision is simple.
I think the President looked at India as the world largest democracy.
It's a key trading partner with the United States, as well as an ally on the War on Terror.
So I'm not surprise that India will be given technology to develop their nuclear technology.

But it sill will pose a danger in terms of our policies, because on one hand, Iran is on the verge of building a nuclear facility, along with North Korea, and this decision may come back to haunt the United States in the future.
India is a very interesting country as it relates to billions upon billions of people that would inhabit that country over the next 50 years.
That will become our largest trading partner outside of China.
And so we have to engage these folks.
I thought it was very interesting, out of the 22 nuclear reactors that India has, they actually wanted four to go under the international inspection treaties.
We actually got that up based on the shuttle diplomacy that we were able to do over the last couple of months to bring that up to 14.
So 14 out of 22 will be under International inspection, which is way much more than Iran would have ever given us--or Korea or anyone else for that matter.
Robert, when you look at President's trip, he went from India to Pakistan.
The U.S.
treats Pakistan as a pariah for its developing nuclear weapons.
And here we are now saying to India well, it's okay.
Is this a double standard?
And I extend this thought to Iran.
I extend it to North Korea.
How do you explain Bush administration policy when it comes to nuclear proliferation?
No question about it, there is a contradiction in our foreign policy.
But the reason why there's contradiction is because it is reality based.
The fact of the matter is is that India is willing to play with us, if you will, and Iran and Korea and some other folks are not.

And so the fact is is that India has said look, Mr. President, look United States we will work with you albeit somewhat cautiously, to open up some of our nuclear reactors, to discuss exactly what we can and cannot do.
Iran and Korea and some other folks are saying we won't even let you in.
We won't even have a conversation with you.

And so basically what I'm trying to say here is that with India at the very least we could have a rational conversation about the future of our countries from a political standpoint, from a social policy standpoint, and from an economic standpoint.
You can't even have that conversation with an Iran or Korea.
Let's move on to another topic, which is politics here in Washington, something you both are intimately involved with.
When you look at the polls these days, the polls for the president have him just about at his nadir ranging from 37, 38 percent to 42 percent in a recent poll.
Vice President Cheney's polls numbers are even worse.
When it comes to control of the Congress, voters are saying they want Democrats in control of the Congress.
Right track, wrong track, again voters are saying the country is on the wrong track.

Robert, all the indicators seem to indicate that this could be another 1994 midterm election, but instead of having the Republicans taking control, this time the Democrats would be reasserting themselves and taking control.
What are you hearing in Republican circles?
We're concerned.
There's no question about it.
We're looking at the poll numbers just like everyone else.

And look, it's obvious that when you take a look at Katrina, the handling of that, when you take a look the port security and the handling of that, when you take a look at the incident with Vice President Cheney and the handling of that, this is an administration that unfortunately has stumbled over its own two feet over the last six months.

And so I think what you're seeing is a natural reaction from the American people by saying, look, Mr. President, you campaigned in 2004 as strong and steady leader that's not going to flip flop, that you know exactly where you're going.
And I think what you're seeing now is the American people scratching their heads and say, well, wait a minute.
Your actions really do not back up with your rhetoric here.
You know, it's very interesting Juan is that you have four leaders, if you will, in the Democratic Party.
You have Pelosi, you have Dean, you have Clinton and you have Reid, and they're all saying four different messages.

And the American people are hearing that and are saying, first, of all not only are they contradicting themselves, number one, but also number two, who is the leader, or who is the rightful leader of the Democratic Party.
And you have to give the Republican credit that naturally because the Republicans obviously controls the house and the Senate and the White House, the president by default is our leader.
So when the president speaks or when Republicans speak it's with one voice.
When the Democrats speaks, it's with four voices.

And unfortunately, out of those four leaders you have Mrs. Clinton or Senator Clinton who is extremely polarizing, and you also have obviously Mr. Dean or Governor Dean who is also polarizing; and you have Pelosi and Reid, who for the most part of their own baggage, if you will.
We have what we call in our party an inside/outside problem.
The insiders, the four individuals that Robert mentioned, they're the ones who are running the ballgame.

But the outsiders, the governors, the state lawmakers, the grassroots activists and the net root activists, they're the ones that are going to provide the momentum and the energy and the turnout mechanism in 2006.

So right now, I tell my friends outside of Washington, D.C., forget what's taken place inside the beltway it's like a soap opera drama, and focus on winning back the Congress from where you live, where you eat, where you play, and where you pray.
Well, thank you so much.

Donna Brazile, Campaign manager for Democratic presidential nominee, Al Gore in 2000, who now runs her own political consulting firm here in Washington; and Robert Traynham, political strategist based in Washington.
Thank you both very much for joining us on political corner.
Thank you, Juan.
Thank you.
Back to you, Ed.
NPR's senior correspondent Juan Williams and our Washington Insiders can be heard here every Thursday on Political Corner.
Well, you know, Republicans have created this don't be happy worry narrative about all kinds of things, including ISIS and the Islamic State and Ebola, and they hope that will carry them to victory.
And there's also been a lot of posturing.
I'm willing to propose a complete ban on flights from countries that don't even have flights - direct flights - to the United States.

It'll - I think it's gotten in the way, certainly, of a set of Democratic arguments that have been advanced most effectively out there not by President Obama but by - whom a lot of Democrats in tough states don't want to campaign for them - but by Elizabeth Warren and both Clintons, around economic issues - equal pay, minimum wage, student loan reduction.

One of the things that strikes me as we go to the end here is while the Republicans probably have an edge at this point, what's really striking is the seats that might have gone into contention and haven't.
So you got Senator Franken's and Minnesota Senator Merkley, they seem safe.
Gary Peters, the Democrat in Michigan.
So it's a tighter race than you would've expected, given President Obama's approval rating.
David, that wasn't the most confident statement from E J about the Democrat's prospects.
No, I'm not going to make stuff up (laughter).
But it was rather positive though.
What you see looking ahead to the election?
Why is E J not going to make stuff up?
Why should this week be any different?
I'm just kidding, just kidding.
Ah, now, low blow, low blow.
No, that's your job, David.
I've got the Louisiana style down here.
You know, I don't see a big Hawaiian style tidal wave on the Republican side.
But they're sort of, like, a Delaware seashore wave so a medium-sized wave.
You know, I think you see it...
Doesn't sound very confident to me either.
No but, I mean, I think it's more likely than not Republicans will take the Senate.
They're doing well in states like Arkansas.
They're making it close in states like New Hampshire so there are clearly some states that are outliers, like Kansas and Georgia.
But you tend to see movement, slight movement, toward the Republicans pretty much nationwide I think because of the feeling of sourness.
The Democrats, E J, count on women voters.
They have spoken about a war on women that the Republicans are waging.
Have they overdone it?
In Colorado, Senator Udall is being derided by his opponent, Senator Uterus.
I mean, you're talking too much about reproductive rights.
Right.
Well, I think the whole argument about the women's vote was never just about reproductive rights.
Equal pay is a big part of it.
And so are the economic issues because women voters historically have shown a real concern for, you know, pocketbook issues, education issues and safety net issues.
What's really striking is that if the Democrats do hold on, women candidates are going to play a big role.
When you see Michelle Nunn putting up a real fight in Georgia that the Republicans didn't expect, Kay Hagan looks like, at the moment, she's going to hold North Carolina.
And then you've got Mary Landrieu being, you know, a central figure and Jeanne Shaheen.
Women are going to play a central part in whether the Democrats win or lose this election.

As the Republicans, David, look at some of those same states and say that if they win back North Carolina and hold Georgia, the road to the White House in 2016 is a little bit more navigable for them.
